question: In the five kingdom classification of Whittaker, there is no mention of ______.
Some acellular organisms like ______ were not included in the five kingdom classification.
Viroids and ______ are also acellular organisms.
Viruses did not find a place in classification since they are not considered truly ______.
Viruses are non-cellular organisms having an inert ______ structure outside the living cell.
Once viruses infect a cell, they replicate by using the host cell’s ______.
The word virus means venom or ______ fluid.
Dmitri Ivanowsky recognised microbes as the cause of ______ disease in tobacco.
Ivanowsky found that the causal microbes passed through ______-proof filters.
M.W. Beijerinck named the new pathogen as ______.
Beijerinck called the virus-containing fluid as Contagium vivum ______.
W.M. Stanley showed that viruses could be ______.
Viral crystals consist largely of ______.
Viruses are inert outside their specific ______ cell.
Viruses are obligate ______.
Viruses contain genetic material that can be either ______ or DNA.
No virus contains both RNA and ______.
A virus is a ______, consisting of protein and genetic material.
In general, plant viruses have ______ stranded RNA.
Animal viruses may have single or double stranded RNA or double stranded ______.
Viruses that infect bacteria are called ______.
Bacteriophages usually contain ______ stranded DNA.
The protein coat of a virus is called ______.
Capsid is made of subunits called ______.
Capsomeres are arranged in ______ or polyhedral geometric forms.
Viruses cause diseases like mumps, ______, herpes, and influenza.
______ in humans is also caused by a virus.
Viruses have an inert crystalline structure ______ the living cell.
Viruses replicate by killing the ______ cell.
Viruses were not included in classification as they lack a ______ structure.
The virus that causes mosaic disease in tobacco was found to pass through ______ filters.
Beijerinck demonstrated that virus extract could infect ______ plants.
Stanley showed that viral crystals are largely made of ______.
Infectious genetic material of viruses is either DNA or ______.
The capsid protects the viral ______ acid.
Capsomeres are arranged in helical or ______ shapes.
Viruses like those causing herpes and ______ are harmful to humans.
Viruses infecting animals may have double stranded ______.
Bacteriophages infect ______.
W.M. Stanley showed that viruses could form ______.
Viruses become active only inside a specific ______.
Contagium vivum fluidum means infectious ______ fluid.
Some viruses contain genetic material in the form of ______ stranded RNA.
The capsid of a virus is made up of repeating units called ______.
Viruses are acellular and exist in an ______ state outside host cells.
Bacteriophages typically contain ______ as their genetic material.
The geometric shape of the virus capsid may be helical or ______.
Viruses that infect plants mostly have ______ stranded RNA.
Flu and ______ are diseases caused by viruses.
No virus has both DNA and ______ together.
The host cell’s machinery is taken over by the ______.
Bacteriophages are viruses that infect ______.
The viral capsid protects the viral ______ material.
Viroids and ______ are not cellular organisms.
Mosaic disease of tobacco is caused by a ______.
Viruses do not have a ______ structure.
The virus fluid was called Contagium vivum ______ by Beijerinck.
Viruses reproduce only inside a specific ______ cell.
Capsomeres form the protective coat called the ______.
Viruses are called obligate ______ because they require host cells to reproduce.
______ Ivanowsky identified the microbe causing mosaic disease of tobacco.
______ demonstrated that the virus extract could infect healthy plants.
______ Stanley showed viruses can be crystallised.
Viruses are neither fully living nor fully ______.
The protein coat of viruses is composed of ______ subunits.
Crystallised viruses consist largely of ______.
AIDS is caused by a ______.
Viruses infect plants, animals and ______.
